Famous Amos

I was reading an article in the most recent Time magazine today about the "civil war" Islam. It started out with a story of a father who lives in Baghdad, and decided to send his son to school in the UAE to escape Saddam's oppression. His son attended a school where he studied automotive maintenance. The family was a very Western family; they didn't wear traditional Muslim garments, his father smoked, and the son regularly attended parties. However, the father started to wonder about his son when the son began to write letters home chiding his father's smoking and his mother wearing Western clothes to work. When his once clean-shaven son returned home after the fall of Saddam's regime, he had a long beard and his disdasha (traditional Islamic gown) was several inches short of the floor. His father knew these were trademarks of Islamic fundamentalists. The son then began to tell him father how the United States was the "enemy" of Islam.
 
 
 Time also tells of a British Pakistani who was a former spokesman for al-Muhajiroun, an extremist group based in Britain. He claims, "I would fit into being called a radical, and one day, God willing, even to be called a terrorist, if Allah permits me. This is something it would be an honor to be called."
 
 
 I just point out these 2 instances to show how many Islamic extremists are putting a bad name on the Islamic religion. They claim that their god, Allah, permits them to remove infidels and even behead them. However, religious scholars say that the Islamic religion condemns this kind of violence in the name of religion. The basic texts of the faith never sanction the wanton murder of civlians, which extremists believe they were brought on this planet to do. When you have people out there who claim that they are inspired by their religion to murder Americans because they are the enemy, you have a problem. I just felt that Time had a really good report and wanted to see what everyone has to say about this issue.
Big Orn

This is a growing trend, Famous Amos. I see no way of stopping it's growth...not from my standpoint anyway. Once you have an established way of life, one that instills "honor" (loosely used here) by doing those harm that oppose that belief/way of life, then you have what I call the New Ishmaels. It is not meant in a discriminatory fashion, but as a means to explain their hatred of all things non-Muslim.
 For example, they see the United States as a bully, a country where killing unborn children is okay, where the freedom to become a legitimate hooker is as paramount as becoming a kindergarten teacher, where lawyers are the law, where the OJ Simpson’s and Scott Peterson’s become celebrities, where a person’s skin color denotes whether he is good or bad…they see this country spreading that “filth” all over them and their own after being subjugated by it. It is and will be an honor for them to kill and be killed to destroy the American Monster, the Infidels.
 And, I’m afraid they’ve only just begun. These older, more experienced murderers/terrorists are their heroes, because to them we are the murderers/terrorists.
 
 It echoes the sentiments, “Know thine enemy.”

 When was the last time a Christian group declared war on a certain religion/race/ethnicity and organized hundreds of suicide bombers to blow themselves up "in the name of God"? Islamic extremists actually believe that the Koran tells them to kill Americans. I don't think any Christian group believes that the Bible tells them that they should kill all Muslims. How often do you see Christians in the United States kill Muslims? Hardly ever. How often do you see Islamic extremists kill Americans in Iraq? All the time.

 It's so easy to look at this situation with exactly those righteous blinders and use apples and oranges comparisons. We're right and good, they're wrong and evil.
 
 The Crusades, the Spanish Inquisition, how about the near extermination of the American Indian? Suicide bombers or not, the outcome and intent was the same.
 
 How many Muslims have invaded the Christian USA? Do you think that American Christians would kill said Muslims if they were threatening their way of life and possibly their freedom? OF COURSE THEY WOULD.
 
 George Bush himself said that God told him going to war was the right thing to do, to "preserve what he believes in". How is that different than a muslim using the Koran to support doing whatever he can do to "preserve what he believes in"? They have fundamentalist clerics, we have Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson. There are posts on this subject active right now.
 
 The muslims think they're right and you think you're right, but in the end, you're both fighting the same war, and you're both demonizing the other for doing the same things.

Waxy is right, Famous Amos. Sad but true. But keep in mind that Hitler used his flavor of Christianity, not Christ's. And as far as Pat Robertson saying "God told him..."? Bull.

Big Orn

Did David Korech call upon his people to blow up 'innocent' people?

 No.
 Did he get innocent people killed? Yes.
 He claimed to be the Lamb of God; he claimed to be Elijah and, from my view, set himself up as God inside that compound and used innocent people as sacrifices. His actions got over 100 innocent people killed.
 
 Here’s the way I see it: If he was a special person, “anointed of God”, and was doing the work God had commanded him, there would have been no bloodshed, there would be no need for 50 caliber machine guns, automatic weapons and HE munitions.
 
 God said in 1John 3 : 15 that if you hate any person you are a murderer. Koresh actually hated those that did not follow his line of reasoning. For example when a young man first joined his league, Koresh asked if the boy would die for Christ, which the boy replied that he would. When asked if he would kill for Christ and answered in the negative, Koresh called him “weak”. 
 
 On the other side: Did the BATF do the right thing? I think not. That’s another reason why we should “know our enemies”.

 Claiming to be the Lamb of God, etc is irrelevant. The lumping together of a his group with a number of other groups seems rather odd. As far as I see it actually gives credence to the ATF case that he was indeed dangerous. It is the excuse they used for attacking his group.
 
 That he gathered together a religious group (albeit an armed one) doesn't as even you recognise invite the reaction that they received. Therefore we both agree that he didn't do something to get his people killed. The analogy therefore fails.
